DOC.HEAD: Mercenary Who Held Islands Says He's Negotiating With South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Bob Denard, leader of the mercenaries who last week were forced to yield their control of the Comoros Islands, said Friday he was negotiating with authorities to leave South Africa as soon as possible. Denard has been in South Africa since Dec. 15, the day French troops landed in the Comoros off southeastern Africa and ended a takeover led by Denard and fellow European mercenaries. The Presidential Guard, which was led by the mercenaries, had controlled the three-island Indian Ocean nation, a former French colony, since the shooting death Nov. 26 of President Ahmed Abdallah. At his first news conference in South Africa, Denard on Friday described his stay in South Africa as ``obviously temporary'' and said he hoped to depart soon after he and his lawyer, who had just arrived from Paris, worked out details. Denard, a Frenchman, thanked South Africa for its hospitality. More than 30 of the mercenaries flew to Europe last week, but Denard was allowed to stay in South Africa temporarily while he negotiated for permanent residence elsewhere. Three of the mercenaries initially stayed with Denard in South Africa, but Foreign Affairs spokesman Rusty Evans said two had returned to France during the week. France and South Africa are the main donors of aid to the Comoros, but they suspended assistance following Abdallah's death in circumstances that remain unclear. Many Comoreans blamed Denard for the killing, but he again denied Friday that he was involved. ``I am not an assassain. I did not kill President Abdallah,'' he said. He has previously said one of the president's bodyguards shot him. Denard has told South African authorities that he was wary of returning to France because he could face criminal charges for his role in an attempted coup in the West African country of Benin 14 years ago.
